description.plain:
Sam Smith was born on 19th May 1992 and grew up in a rural village on the border of Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire, the nearest town being Bishops Stortford. They’re the oldest of three siblings and are said to be close to their younger sisters. Their mother is a successful City of London trader and their father is a stay-at-home dad who brought up the children.

Smith showed an early talent for singing, and their parents responded by arranging singing lessons from the age of eight with professional jazz singer and songwriter, Joanna Eden. At the early age of seventeen, they left school to pursue their dream, living in a small one-bed flat and working in a London pub, but ended up isolated and beset by loneliness.

Sam knew they were gay, they said, for as long as they could remember. They suffered bullying at school and were shocked to find that even in London—close to gay communities—they were subjected to homophobic attacks. These negative experiences, combined with an inherently emotional nature, inform their songwriting and delivery. The soulful, beautifully rich tone of their voice and the subject of the lyrics ‘speak’ to many people and have led to their success.

 It was through collaboration with Disclosure’s “Latch” and Naughty Boy’s “La La La”, Smith found themselves more and more in-demand throughout 2012 and 2013. They publicly came out as gay shortly before releasing their debut album In the Lonely Hour on 26 May 2014, which they wrote because they were in love with a man who “didn’t love [them] back”.

In 2015 Sam won the Grammys for Best New Artist, Record of the Year and Best Pop Vocal Album. Their popular single “Stay With Me” won the 2015 Grammy for Song of the Year.

In 2017 Sam came out as non-binary stating “I feel as much a woman as I am a man”, and in 2019 announced on Instagram that they were changing their pronouns to the gender neutral they/them.  In subsequent interviews Sam confessed that “… gender, for me, has been nothing but traumatising” and that they weren’t prepared for the “ridicule” that was directed at them.

In terms of professional life, Sam’s career has been nothing but successful. In September 2017 Sam’s single ‘Too Good at Goodbyes’, the lead single of their sophomore album, was released. It topped the charts in their home country and reached the top five in the U.S. It has accumulated over a billion views on the streaming service, YouTube. In early November, their album ‘The Thrill Of It All’ managed to top the official charts of eleven countries.

On March 20, 2018, Sam began their “The Thrill of It All World Tour” in Sheffield, England. It visited Europe, North America, Asia, New Zealand and Australia. The South Africa leg of the tour began in Cape Town, but was cut short by what at the time was said to be voice strain and Sam’s fear that they would damage their voice further if the tour continued. However, they subsequently admitted to panic and stress following the grief of their break-up with ex-boyfriend, Brandon Flynn.

On 27 March 2018, they released “Pray” featuring American rapper Logic. On 17 August 2018, the singer collaborated as the main vocalist on Calvin Harris’s new track “Promises”. The song became Smith’s seventh number one hit on the UK Singles Chart.

In January 2019, Sam Smith released the R&B-tinged, somewhat autobiographical ‘'Dancing with a Stranger", a timely collaboration with Fifth Harmony’s starlet Normani – a girl group that Sam has been a huge fan of.

In July 2019 “How Do You Sleep" was released, accompanied by a music video that garnered a hundred million views in less than two months. Sam has said in an interview with Kiss Radio that the story behind the song is broadly autobiographical.

In October 2019 Sam received the Person of the Year award from Attitude Magazine for their campaigning on behalf of the non-binary community.

On 1st November 2019 Sam released a cover, to positive reviews, of I Feel Love, originally released by Donna Summer in 1977.

Sam’s prolific output didn’t end in 2019. In 2020 Sam’s single To Die For was released in February 2020. Intended as the title track of their album, planned initially for release in May, this was deferred because of the global Coronavirus pandemic. The title and content were deemed inappropriate have been revised.

On 18th September 2020 the second single Diamonds from Sam’s third album, re-titled Love Goes was released.  The full album dropped on 30th October 2020.  A significant proportion of the tracks have been attributed by Sam themself to their relationship and break-up with Brandon Flynn.

description.plain:
“Too Good at Goodbyes” tells of a turbulent personal relationship, and is Sam Smith’s first solo release since their 2015 James Bond theme “Writing’s on the Wall.” The song is the lead single from their sophomore album, The Thrill of It All.

In a Beats 1 interview, Sam explained that only four songs on the album are about them, and “Too Good at Goodbyes” is one of them. They told Zane Lowe how the song was inspired by a real relationship:

[The song is] about a relationship I was in and it’s basically about getting good at getting dumped. […] I’m still very, very single. I think I’m even more single than I was when I released In the Lonely Hour.

They also said,

At the time I was trying to convince myself I was tough, to protect myself. I was gearing up for what I knew would happen. I’m really not like that at all.

In an interview with Nick Grimshaw on BBC Radio 1 on the morning the song dropped, Nick introduced Sam by saying that “the vibes around Sam have definitely changed,” and Sam agreed. They explained that the album, due in November, is a tribute to the family and friends who supported them over the years, focusing on ‘their lives — their ups and downs’, rather than Sam’s own.

description.plain:
“Stay with Me” sees Smith yearning for a lasting relationship after a one-night stand leaves them craving more. One of their biggest hits, it’s gone #1 in countries like the United States, Canada, and Ireland, and even won two Grammy awards.

Written with Jimmy Napes and Tourist in Old Street, London studio, Smith claimed “the song just flowed out of us so naturally.” When Tourist played the first three chords, Napes quickly added a drum layer, and the rest of the track took only 30-40 minutes to write.

Upon the track’s release, listeners noticed similarities between “Stay With Me” and Tom Petty’s 1989 hit “I Won’t Back Down.” Smith’s team said that this was purely coincidental, but agreed to give Petty co-writer credits, and Petty stated that he has no ill feelings for Smith.

The music video was directed by Jamie Thraves, who also directed the music videos for Smith’s “Money On My Mind,” Radiohead’s “Just,” Coldplay’s “The Scientist,” by and Death Cab for Cutie’s “I Will Follow You into the Dark.” It features Sam walking down the street in Hackney, London, among other settings.

description.plain:
“I’m Not the Only One” is Smith’s slow realisation that their lover has been cheating on them and lying about it when Smith voices their suspicions. Smith loved him so much and they put so much of themself into the relationship that their heart won’t let them stop loving him even when they want to.

It was released in the United Kingdom as a digital download on 31 August 2014 as the fifth single from his debut studio album, In the Lonely Hour (2014). The song was written by Smith and Jimmy Napes.

An official remix of the track, featuring two verses from American rapper A$AP Rocky, premiered on 9 September 2014.

description.plain:
“Pray” is the second single from Sam Smith’s sophomore album The Thrill of it All. The song follows lead single “Too Good at Goodbyes”, which dropped just four weeks earlier.

The song combines strong gospel influnces with a hip hop beat, courtesy of Timbaland, who co-produced the song with Jimmy Napes.

Smith told Billboard that “Pray” was inspired by a visit to Iraq:

I spent five days in Mosul and came back ­embarrassed that I had known so little about the world and other people’s lives…I wanted to write about what is going on in the rest of the world, and that it’s not always pretty.

The tone of the lyric is searingly self-critical; a ‘coming-of-age’ song involving feelings of shame, guilt, newly raised awareness, and ultimately some degree of trust in whatever Power they feel might exists.

It is also a markedly intelligent song, indicating Sam’s grasp of the shortcomings and immaturity of many young people, and the shocks and processes that lead to self-growth and a compassionate outlook.

Sam Smith performed the song at the 2018 Grammy Awards.

description.plain:
http://instagram.com/p/yg29Dpx2e4/
The first single from Sam’s debut album, In The Lonely Hour.

Much of In the Lonely Hour deals with a case of unrequited love Smith suffered when they fell for a straight man and thus not interested in their advances. The singer explained during their performance at the O2 Academy in Brixton, London that they wrote “Lay Me Down” after deleting the unresponsive man from thier social media account.

Smith explained to MTV News how this was the song that kick-started their music career:

“Disclosure heard ‘Lay Me Down,’ and (after that) it was like a domino effect,” he said. “We wrote ‘Latch’ together, and then Naughty Boy heard ‘Latch’ and we wrote ‘La La La’ together, and then I had a number-one single in the UK.”

The song was re-recorded for a 2015 re-release following Smith’s commercial success.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HaMq2nn5ac0

description.plain:
After weeks of teasing on Sam’s social media sites, this song was released on July 19th 2019. Sam said that they wanted to move on from heartbreak ballads, commenting in a press release:

This year, both personally and musically, I feel so free. More than ever I have had so much fun making this record and this video…

The song is characterised by a hypnotic beat and danceable rhythm. The melody has features of Sam’s style, notably showcasing their vocal range and the distinctive timbre of their voice. The lyric, however, is of heartache and resentment – a story typical of Sam.

The accompanying music video also marks a departure, in that it features Sam’s considerable dancing skills; an unexpected surprise.

description.plain:
Sam Smith  confirmed on 8 September 2015 that he  recorded the James Bond theme song. He said on his social media:

This is one of the highlights of my career. I am honoured to finally announce that I will be singing the next Bond theme song. I am so excited to be a part of this iconic British legacy and join an incredible line up of some of my biggest musical inspirations.  I hope you all enjoy the song as much as I enjoyed making it.

Sam dropped the first major hint that he would be recording the theme song when he shared a snap of him wearing a ring emblazoned with the Spectre logo on 7 September 2015.

https://instagram.com/p/7VWisvR2Vl/

In an interview on the BBC Radio 1 Breakfast Show with Nick Grimshaw, he told that he co-wrote the song with long-time collaborator Jimmy Napes in twenty minutes. “It’s the quickest song I’ve ever written. The actual vocal on the song is my demo.” He recorded the song in January 2015.

I wanted to make the most classic, most timeless Bond song and also tried to make it an epic love song. That’s all I’m saying.

Commenting on the announcement, Bond producers Michael G. Wilson and Barbara Broccoli said:

Sam and Jimmy have written the most inspirational song for Spectre and with Sam’s extraordinary vocal performance, “Writing’s On The Wall” will surely be considered one of the greatest Bond songs of all time.

Sam Smith is the first British male solo artist to sing the Bond theme since 1965, when Tom Jones performed the task for Thunderball (Paul McCartney and Simon Le Bon also sang vocals for Bond themes, but these were credited as band performances).

The single was an international hit, and became the first Bond theme to hit #1 in the UK.

It won the Oscar for Best Original Song at the 88th Academy Awards in 2016.

description.plain:
Sam Smith’s emotional vocals in “Fire on Fire” feature on the BBC and Netflix mini-series Watership Down, an adaptation of the eponymous 1972 Richard Adams novel, which debuted 23 December 2018. The story is an unfortunate tale of a herd of rabbits living in the town of Watership Down in England.

“Fire on Fire” follows Sam Smith’s collaboration with Calvin Harris on “Promises.” The fiery track, recorded in September 2018, perfectly mimics the beautiful-yet-ensuing chaos featured in the music video.

The song is notable for displaying Sam’s wide vocal range, reaching a lower-than-usual register.

description.plain:
In an interview with Nick Grimshaw on BBC Radio 1 Nick introduced Sam by saying that “the vibes around Sam have definitely changed,” and Sam agreed. They explained that, unlike ‘In the Lonely Hour’ which was largely about a one-sided love affair, this album is a tribute to the family and friends who have supported them over the years, focusing on ‘their lives — their ups and downs’, rather than their own.

This song is not about Sam but a friend or family member who decided, with sadness, to end a relationship.  Beyond that, the song is somewhat mysterious, as Sam has clearly preferred not to divulge someone else’s personal information. However, Sam has said that ‘I hope this song has helped them’.'

The ‘Midnight Train’ of the title can be taken as a metaphor. While it is possible that the speaker did literally slip away at night, the idea of a near-empty, late night train is symbolic, rather mournful, suggesting a sad, lone traveller escaping from a relationship that wasn’t working. And midnight, of course, is a time of mystery and danger, the singer facing a new day and an uncertain future.

description.plain:
In an interview with Zane Lowe for Beats 1 Radio Sam said that ‘This was written in Nashville. I was looking back on the ghosts of my lovers.’ They expanded this further in an intimate performance in London for Apple Music, when they explained to the audience;

I was thinking of my heart as a palace of rooms and in every single room was a ghost … all the guys I’ve slept with (cheers, laughter and applause!). I wrote this song because no matter how many times my heart breaks, how many shit relationships I go through, real love is never a waste of time.

The song is about many relationships and, maybe, also one particular relationship.  The point is that all were worthwhile.

The extended metaphor of the Palace representing past loves attests to the development of Sam’s lyrical skills. The only jarring note is possibly — as some critics have commented —  the mundane, rather un-poetic ‘true love is never a waste of time’. But that is a minor quibble. Sam was twenty-five when they wrote this and future years of lyric writing will refine their skills.

description.plain:
“To Die For” is a mid-tempo, pop-soul ballad. The song comes after releasing several dance numbers in the previous eighteen months, such as “How Do You Sleep?,” “Dancing With a Stranger,” and “Promises.” Sam wrote on Twitter: “I poured my heart and soul into this song,” and on Instagram: “[…] I’ve really set myself free the last two years whilst writing this,” a reference, perhaps, to coming out as non-binary.

The song was originally the title track for Sam’s third album, but months later it was reviewed and deemed inappropriate due to the coronavirus pandemic. The revised album was finally released in October 2020, entitled Love Goes.

description.plain:
A standout on The Thrill Of It All, “HIM” is a story of a boy coming out of the closet to a combined father/priest/God figure. This boy wishes to make those who disapprove understand that no matter how hard he tries, nothing and no one can change him. Note that this is not a story about Sam, who has always praised their parents for their support and acceptance of who and what they are.

In an interview with NME Sam spoke at length about this track, saying,

This is not my story … it’s for the LGBT Community.

They also refer to the intolerance in some American states. Their reference in the song to ‘the streets of Mississippi’ is a metaphor for all intolerant societies, including Australia where, they say, the situation for the LGBT community ‘… is not where it should be.’ After years of ‘coming out’ stories in past decades, in many communities nothing has changed. So the stories need re-telling again and again for every generation.

Mississippi scared the shit out of me and I wanted to write about it. I am gay and my music is gay. It’s so important to speak about this … we should be addressing these issues. We should be talking — shouting about this.

The assertive tone of the NME interview is mirrored in the lyric, notably the line where the boy says ‘Don’t you try to tell me that God doesn’t care for us (gay people).’ For all his trepidation this boy can give a sharp rebuke to the priest/father figure.

The gospel influences in the production, especially the choir, fit the mournful yet angst-ridden mood. In an Apple Music video, entitled ‘On the Record; The Thrill of it All’, Brendan Grieve, bass player who was responsible for much of the production, described the sound as ‘stark gospel’. Pianist, Reuben James, also commented that the title is ‘… a play on words. We wanted it to be in the style of a traditional hymn.’

description.plain:
“Diamonds” is the second official single by English singer Sam Smith, taken from their third studio album, Love Goes. The upbeat song, follows July 2020’s first single “My Oasis” with Burna Boy

Along with the release of the song, Smith took to social media to announce the new release date of their third studio album, as well as the new cover art, track-list, and cover art.

Sam wrote:

The last two years have been the most experimental time of my life, personally but also musically. Every time I went into the studio I promised myself I would shoot for the stars and have no limitations.

“Diamonds” is a fast-tempo electro-pop production with a strong beat, in minor key, and marks a new departure in style for Sam.

Rolling Stone magazine reported that “Sam is reborn — three minutes and 34 seconds of catharsis. Smith sings of a lying love who cared more about the star’s fame and material goods than their heart.” It adds that the song is a “dance-floor anthem … a catchy bass line comes in just in time for the chorus. … The song’s rhythm section is joined by a funky guitar riff that makes the listener want to body-roll their blues away.”

Billboard Magazine described the song as a “heartbreaking track, juxtaposed onto a deliciously synth-y beat.”

The last two years have been the most experimental time of my life, personally but also musically. Every time I went into the studio I promised myself I would shoot for the stars and have no limitations.

“Diamonds” is a fast-tempo electro-pop production with a strong beat, in minor key, and marks a new departure in style for Sam.

Rolling Stone magazine reported that “Sam is reborn — three minutes and 34 seconds of catharsis. Smith sings of a lying love who cared more about the star’s fame and material goods than their heart.” It adds that the song is a “dance-floor anthem … a catchy bass line comes in just in time for the chorus. … The song’s rhythm section is joined by a funky guitar riff that makes the listener want to body-roll their blues away.”

Billboard Magazine described the song as a “heartbreaking track, juxtaposed onto a deliciously synth-y beat.”

description.plain:
In their interview with Zane Lowe for Beats 1 Radio, Sam Smith said that, after their broken relationship,

… the guy I wrote the first record about started to leak back into my mind. … and I didn’t like it.'

They added that ‘I was in Nashville when I wrote this and I woke up and was really angry that morning. There’s an angst in that song’.

In the same interview Sam stated definitively that this was the last time they would write about the man who was the subject of ‘In the Lonely Hour’.

description.plain:
“Burning” sees Sam Smith reconcile themself to the break up of an important relationship, and the pain and unhappiness that it caused them. They have also said that the song is about fame, the pressures of a lifestyle for which they were utterly unprepared, and found difficult to cope with. They believed that this undermined their attempts to form a fulfilling relationship.

Sam uses fire as a symbol for the emotional pain and hurt. In their October 5, 2017 Beats 1 interview with Zane Lowe, Sam described the song as the “core” of The Thrill of It All. They also revealed that there are “only four songs” on the album about themself and their romantic life —“Burning” seems to be one of them.

The song, first aired on 26 October 2017 on BBC Radio 1 Annie Mac Show, is a spare, deceptively simple arrangement that showcases Sam’s voice. The backing piano, played by Reuben James, and the gospel-style chorus in the final verse provide appropriately subtle, subdued accompaniment.

description.plain:
Sam Smith wasn’t bothered about the money when it came to negotiating their record deal, so it’s appropriate that they chose “Money On My Mind” as the lead single for their debut single. On the track, they sing about the importance of artistic integrity and independence.

This track inverts the sentiments of Lil Wayne’s “Money On My Mind.”

description.plain:
In an interview with Zane Lowe for Beats 1 Radio, Sam said of the relationship that inspired their first album,

This song is about ‘In the Lonely Hour’, getting lost in a relationship and getting lost in fame … it’s the last I’ll write about that period of my life.

Sam expanded this by saying that at times fame has been hard to cope with emotionally, and interfered with their attempts for form a loving relationship. So, the first line, ‘I regret that I told the world that you were with me’ refers to how a relationship, once publicised, can come to an end under the pressure.  Towards the end of the worldwide In the Lonely Hour tour they had low moments when this song was written.

description.plain:
When a friend sent a Youtube clip of Yebba Smith singing Sam Smith was captivated by her voice. In an Apple Music interview entitled ‘On the Record; The Thrill of it All’, they talked about the impact of her singing, which they said ‘spoke to me … I felt she could teach me so much…’

Yebba (Abbey spelt backwards) was invited to London, joined Sam and their team in the recording studio, and the result was the duet, ‘No Peace’.  Sam explained that

No Peace' isn’t about a relationship. It’s about being in a really uncomfortable place, about not being still in your mind, being unable to sleep.

Sam said that they were recovering from the unsettling effect of three frantic years of fame, as well as a failed love affair. Yebba’s distress was more serious, the ‘suicide of my Mom’.

The rapport between the two singers is evident in the track. Yebba has commented about Sam that she had ‘a feeling of truth’ about them. ‘I know who you are … who you’ve been and who you will be.’

description.plain:
Sam Smith, in their interview with Zane Lowe for Beats 1 Radio, said that

This is the only happy love song I’ve ever written. My feelings were getting a lot stronger … it’s sad that I couldn’t say it first … and he never did … But I was in a most hopeful and beautiful place.

In response to Zane’s comment that ‘you seem to be protecting yourself’ Sam replied,

It’s not my time yet … I’m twenty-five. I didn’t meet gay people till I was eighteen. I’m very young in terms of love and romance.

description.plain:
“Like I Can” was released as a digital download on 5 December 2014 as the fifth single from Sam Smith’s debut studio album, In the Lonely Hour (2014).

Its lively, hypnotic beat makes it an excellent dance number, with an immediate appeal, maybe the first song to make an impact on new listeners to Sam’s first album. Placed in order of play between two sad sections of the album it is a good contrast. It also shows Sam’s versatility; they are as comfortable with dance rhythms, such as thier recordings with [Disclosure(https://genius.com/artists/Disclosure), as with their trademark soulful, sad compositions.



The song was written by Smith and Matt Prime and produced by Steve Fitzmaurice, Jimmy Napes and Mojam.

description.plain:
This song is unusual, a tribute by a young singer to his parents. Sam has often spoken appreciatively of the support and encouragement given to him by his mother and father, for example in the interview with Zane Lowe for Beats 1 Radio recorded in the lead-up to the launch of ‘The Thrill of it All’.

‘Scars’ is a tribute with a difference in that, despite the unravelling and break-up of his parents' marriage and the distress it caused, he values them and his upbringing unconditionally. This story can be traced back several years to a small dedication at the end of a long list of thanks in the notes for In the Lonely Hour, where Sam wrote;

Mum and Dad … we all have been through so much together … remember what I said to you on that park bench in New York — when you are happy — I am happy.

So, as well as being a song about dedicated parents who supported their children through a marital break-up, it is also an unconscious tribute to the maturity and understanding of Sam and his sisters.

description.plain:
In their interview with Zane Lowe for Beats1 Radio, Sam explained that this song was written after being “dumped over the phone”. They were at home with a friend and their sister who supported them through the heartache:

And we put it on the back burner, I can think about being dumped tomorrow

The song reflects this, with upbeat rhythm and energetic background chorus, a positive lyric telling of sadness, but also determination and resilience — a departure from the passive, sad songs that characterised Sam’s previous album, In the Lonely Hour.

Sam has said that they intended more variety and depth in this album — “Up till now all I’d written were songs about love and being sad.” Both this song and “Too Good at Goodbyes” represent a desire to toughen themselves, even if this wasn’t their true nature.

description.plain:
Nirvana is the second song on Sam Smith’s Debut EP, Nirvana, and is also the second most popular song on the album after Latch.



The mood of this song is more positive than many of the sadder songs in Sam’s repetoire. This is a story of a temporary attraction, yet they seem to feel positive about it. The later songs on the ‘In the Lonely Hour’ collection are full of pain and loneliness, as if Sam fell into a trough of depression before climbing out again. It’s good to know that, despite being a sensitive and emotional person, they are resilient.

The acoustic version of the song is as popular as the original and for many the more subtle and compelling one. The minimal backing instrumentals  — guitar, piano and cello — feed into the thoughful, emotional mood.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sEcJS1G6wss

description.plain:
Called “the saddest song I have ever written,” “Drowning Shadows” is the title track from the Drowning Shadows Edition re-release of Sam Smith’s 2014 debut album, In The Lonely Hour. The track describes Smith’s feelings of loneliness while living in London – as they described in an interview with Zane Lowe, it was written with a literal crossroads in mind:

One road would lead to gay clubs that I used to go out to and then the other road would go home and I was in such a lonely, sad place when I was writing this album that sometimes I would literally have to choose, ’Do I go home to nothing? Or stay out for more?’ And that was a genuine choice for me some nights.”

“Drowning Shadows” was written before many of the hits from In The Lonely Hour, including “Stay With Me” and “I’m Not The Only One”, but wasn’t included on the album because Smith felt the production never fit the song well. They revisited the song while discussing the album repackage with their label, and “it came alive again” when they sang it with a simple piano accompaniment.

An unreleased recording of the song from St. Pancras Old Church in London surfaced online in early 2015. Its official release came on November 2, 2015 as Zane Lowe’s World Record on Beats 1.

This song is powerful and many will relate to it. Apart from Sam’s pure, haunting voice which expresses the meaning so effectively, many listeners admire their honesty and courage in telling this story of casual sex, drink and unhappiness. In interviews they sound upbeat and anything but self-pitying, yet their performances are heart-breaking. It is this combination — controlled and unique voice; sincere, relatable and skilled song-writing; a story that is searingly sad — that has won Sam their fans and success.

The song shares similarities with “Drowning Shadow” to the slow 2nd Movement of Rachmaninov’s 2nd Piano Concerto. It is unlikely that Sam Smith intended this though, and no comments have been made about the similarities either.

description.plain:
‘Not In That Way’ is a song about unrequited love, and the emotional stages of telling someone you love them, but they don’t love you in the same way. It can have meaning for everyone; here we can assume it is a gay man in love with a straight man, as Sam has indicated it is their personal story. But it can also apply to two women, or a heterosexual friendship where one feels more physically attracted than the other. It is, in short, a song about the trials of love and heartbreak.

‘Not in that Way’ and ‘Drowning Shadows’ both featured on In the Lonely Hour; Drowning Shadows Edition are probably the two saddest songs in Sam Smith’s repertoire. Their second album, The Thrill Of It All, also includes songs of heartbreak, notably ‘Burning’ and ‘Nothing Left For You’. Sam has the knack of expressing the pain and grief of love in a way that many listeners relate to.

description.plain:
This is the last song on the album. Before taking a year and a half break (though he did produce this album during that time) Sam explained that they needed to spend time with their family and friends, because ‘It had been all about me for three years and I didn’t know them any more, I needed to be with them, to learn about their lives, their ups and downs.’ In an interview with Zane Lowe for Beats 1 Radio Sam said that,

This is a love letter to my friends. To Hampstead (where they have their home) and to the Heath.

Hampstead is a beautiful and expensive part of North London, home to many celebrities and successful gay people. Hampstead Heath is a green, wooded, urban oasis, a popular spot for picnics, where the press has spotted Sam with their friends and printed unoffical photographs.

Hampstead is a beautiful and expensive part of North London, home to many celebrities and successful gay people. Hampstead Heath is a green, wooded, urban oasis, a popular spot for picnics, where the press has spotted Sam with their friends and printed unoffical photographs.

description.plain:
In terms of genre this song ventures into what may be broadly described as American folk/rock. It is characterised by a slow beat and spare guitar accompaniment, joined by gospel choir and piano, and finally strings. Sam Smith’s voice dominates, with their full vocal range at full power.

The song is about a man who is unable to move on from a past relationship. Sam explains this to a prospective lover; how they are unable to fall in love again.

Unlike most of the other songs on the album Sam has said nothing about this track, so their thoughts and aims remain a mystery.

Shortly after his feature on Tinashe’s “Pretend”, Flacko brings two new verses to the table, this time over UK sensation Sam Smith’s new single “I’m Not the Only One”.

description.plain:
Since Sam Smith’s last album in 2017, there has been a steady stream of new singles. The third Sam Smith album, originally entitled To Die For was planned for Spring 2020, but the Covid-19 pandemic rendered the title and some of the content unsuitable.  The album, retitled Love Goes was dropped on 30 October and this is the fourth track.

This track, co-written with Jimmy Napes and Burna Boy, is a mid-tempo love song with a strong beat. The lyric draws on the themes of developing love and emotional insecurity.

In its review Billboard Magazine wrote:

Sam Smith is straddling two worlds — the past, where he sang soulful, heartbroken ballads, and the present, where the star has begun to present more pop-forward tracks. On “My Oasis,” Smith fuses the two into an entrancing, club/bedroom hybrid single, complete with a drilling beat and hypnotic bells to heighten the mood. When Nigerian superstar Burna Boy jumps on the track, he blends in his own style into the mix, making their latest song complex and vastly different from anything else you’ll hear today.

description.plain:
Sam Smith’s songs are always different; always tell an interesting and usually sad story. Here they launch straight in, as if in the middle of a conversation, a technique that captures the listeners interest immediately. They use metaphor to describe how difficult relationships can be; and telling someone you love them is most difficult of all. Perhaps the saddest is ‘waiting for a friend’ and they don’t turn up —something painful and humiliating that one remembers all one’s life.

It is interesting that Sam has said they were bullied at school, and maybe this is a painful personal memory.

Sam Smith is a master of contrasting volume and effect. Most of the songs on “In the Lonely Hour” escalate to the explosive emotional climax with restraint so subtle you can hear the guitarist’s fingers on the fret board. “What the hell,” Smith growls, before asking the one question we all ask ourselves when everything goes to shit: “Why?” -Billboard



The song tells of a badly handled relationship, with an unexpectedly aggressive responses from Sam. It is unexpected because Sam is warm-hearted and makes friends readily and is generally liked in the industry. This song will strike a cord for all those who make mistakes in how we relate to people — which we all do. Their songs are always relatable.

description.plain:
The acoustic version of ‘Latch’ appears on the ‘In the Lonely Hour’ album, a slower, pared down version of the original.

The two versions seem popular for different reasons, but the acoustic version ( an incredible 13 million hits) has the distinctive Sam Smith emotion and depth.  The slow version showcases his enormous vocal range, power and vocal control.

From the comments it seems many couples choose the slow version to walk down the isle to, or as the first dance at their wedding.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pUK6HlzNWEg

description.plain:
“Good Thing” sees Smith mourning an unrequited love for a man who doesn’t return their feelings. They explained to The Fader in 2014 that much of In The Lonely Hour was inspired by this experience.

It’s worth noting that Smith sings this song in a lower register than is typical for their music, which reflects the sad, difficult situation they’re describing. In addition, rather than showcasing falsetto or other interesting vocal techniques, Smith focuses on telling the story.

Smith stated in an interview with The Line of Best Fit, that “Good Thing” happens to be their most personal song on the album.

description.plain:
“Young,” the first track from Sam Smith’s third studio album Love Goes, tackles the immense pressure Smith felt during the beginning of their career.

Following the track’s release, Smith sat down with Clara Amfo for an interview for BBC Sounds where they commented on the decision to put “Young” as the opening track:

I wanted this to be an honest declaration before we get into the record, I want people to forgive me [for the mistakes I make, for being young].

In making this track Sam indicated also that they wanted “a chance to have fun.” This acapella song is the first of what they regarded as “little momentos,” experimenting with “different characters, different clothes”, so that each song is completely unique.

description.plain: The spare simplicity of this ballad, reminiscent of Sam Smith’s early style, is what gives it its impact. The piano and solo cello backing is all that is needed, and the slow, rhythmic pace is like a heart beat. The song’s effectiveness depends most of all on Sam’s voice, which displays its remarkable vocal range. The  high notes convey the pain of a failed romance; a track to cry to.

description.plain:
A track from Smith’s debut album In the Lonely Hour and also a promotional iTunes Single of the Week.



Unlike many other popular songs that fall into the ‘moon’ and ‘June’ rhyming trap, Sam’s songs tell interesting stories. They also use metaphor to describe their situation and painful emotions.

So in “Life Support,” they sing that “the darkness is surrounding you” —  a way of saying that the object of their love brings them only sadness or “darkness.” They need the lights on to give their life some warmth, something positive. Waking up when the “sky is painted blue” is a poignant way of saying they wake up depressed, and that the world around them — the blue-painted sky — reflects their feelings.

This is a situation that many people will relate to; the reason Sam’s songs chime with many listeners. Of course, the emotion they inject into the songs adds to the impact.

description.plain:
This is an oddity amongst Sam Smith songs. It is unlike anything else they have released, and seems to be the least listened to, according to the number of YouTube views. As far as I am aware they have never sung it live in concert.

Released in 2013 it could be broadly described as ‘electro-soul’. It was co-written by Sam Smith and Ben Ash (otherwise known as ‘Two-Inch Punch’). There are very few comments by YouTube viewers, but most are positive. However, it could be said that Sam’s remarkable voice doesn’t need electronic distortion; it stands alone, too good and distinctive to meddle with. Another view is that, perhaps, their heart wasn’t in this song; it lacks the emotion and depth that Sam puts into the songs that express their soul and real-life experiences.

description.plain:
In terms of the concept of the album, this song is well placed, effectively the last new track before the previously-released bonus tracks. After the opening song, “Young”, which is an apology for youthful excess and irresponsibility, this comes “like a bookend” after the deeply sad, life-changing experiences that follow.  “Kids Again” is about maturity and lost innocence.

When Sam Smith was interviewed by Clara Amfo for BBC Sounds  both remarked that there are echoes of 1970s and 1980s music, and particularly the work of Fleetwood Mac in this track.  It is, Sam commented, different in style to anything else on the album.

Sam added that “this is a bridge to my next record”, expressing the intention to move on from the style of Love Goes to involve themself more in the intricacies of production and “rootsy queer soul”.

description.plain: This is the third track on Love Goes, influenced, according to Sam, by Swedish singer Robyn.  A few months after a relationship break-up while on “The Thrill of it All” tour, Sam learned that their former lover had met someone else. On this track, they sing of the emotions they felt — a mix of generosity and sadness and bitterness; of sincerity, sarcasm and resentment. The track has a gentle, mid-tempo but strong beat and jazz influences.

description.plain:
As implied by its title, “Restart” returns to the record’s upbeat beginning and dials it up a notch. To drive the point home, he scratches and rewinds his verses.-Billboard



There’s something about this track that is different. It doesn’t seem like a personal story, not autobiographical like the sad tracks on ‘In the Lonely Hour’. Sam’s song writing skills are versatile and they may have felt the need to lighten the album with an upbeat number. It’s a relief to hear a lyric that suggests the strong, more carefree side of Sam.

description.plain:
In an interview with Clara Amfo for BBC Sounds Sam said they wanted “So Serious” to be “like a cute pop song” but “deep lyrically”. The story of Sam’s relationship break-up is searingly sad.

Yet the result is like an ironic version of ‘If You’re Happy and You Know it Clap Your Hands’.  It is light and gentle with a catchy, dance-able rhythm, a singalong, disco-style pop song that stays in the mind.

description.plain:
This track has a slow emphatic beat and a subtle backing that grows stronger through the song, adding a sense of energy. Sam said when interviewed by Clara Amfo for BBC Sounds  that “this is looking inwards”, an indication that in a relationship “you can both mess up”.

Although Sam acknowledged that the lyric seems depressing they indicated that ultimately in all their relationships the aim should be positive, ending with mutual respect, a view similar to that expressed in the song Palace from the album The Thrill Of It All.

description.plain:
Sam Smith’s first solo single, which did not chart when it was originally released in 2013, but had greater success after being re-recorded for a re-release in 2015. Smith re-recorded “Lay Me Down” a third time, collaborating with John Legend, for Comic Relief 2015, and it topped the UK singles chart.

Sam Smith’s first solo single, which did not chart when it was originally released in 2013, but had greater success after being re-recorded for a re-release in 2015. Smith re-recorded “Lay Me Down” a third time, collaborating with John Legend, for Comic Relief 2015, and it topped the UK singles chart.
In this third recording of “Lay Me Down”, John Legend plays the backing piano and his vocals join the song at the second verse.

description.plain:
On “Dance (‘Til You Love Someone Else),” Sam Smith presents a message about the pain of getting over someone you’ve broken up with. While attending an interview with Apple Music, Sam mentioned that this dance-pop ballad is like a sequel to their collaboration with Normani titled, “Dancing with a Stranger.” Furthermore, in the same interview, Sam said:

If on ‘Dancing with a Stranger’ I’m sexy, heartbroken and dancing with a stranger feeling sad, on this one I’m going out and I need to find someone to heal that feeling. I need to mask the heartbreak immediately with someone else.

On the surface, the song seems akin to grieving over a lover — no doubt Brandon Flynn. Smith, though, says it’s something more sinister, remarking:

It’s more aggressive, darker and more desperate. There’s angst to this song and it’s a bit more hedonistic.

description.plain:
This Christmas single dropped unexpectedly on 20th November 2020 with no promotion. Written in partnership with Labrinth it is unlike anything Sam Smith has produced before. It is a throwback to the 1940s, a song with a story of Christmas reunion. The result is an unusual mix of sombre anthem and gentle lullaby, with classical-style choral backing and soft strings.  The Christmas theme is subtle; the reference “home for Christmas time” doesn’t come until the end of verse two.

The accompanying music video is a charming animated cartoon with a theme of departing and taking risks, but returning to love and safety. The credits attribute the direction to Sam Smith.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kvULB5R2SLA

description.plain:
This song was composed by Sam Smith for their album In the Lonely Hour, but a decision was subsequently made not to include it. It was also ‘pulled’ from Youtube, although Sam can be heard singing it in a recording of an early concert in May 2013 at St Pancras Old Church in London. Sam has never given a reason for excluding it.

The song has an emphatic, hypnotic, bluesy beat that is reminiscent of the Grammy-winning song “Stay With Me.” Sam’s voice has the distinctive mature, rich quality of their later work. The public response to the Youtube clip is one-hundred-per-cent positive. One interesting comment is that ‘the melody flows naturally as if it’s always existed and just waiting for Sam to write it.’

The lyric is self-explanatory and needs very little annotation. We can speculate that maybe its lack of sophistication caused it to be rejected, and certainly the songs on In the Lonely Hour  are more complex. Whatever the motivation the melody and Sam’s voice have reached the level of maturity of their later work. The song is an interesting one in the development of Sam’s song-writing and performing skills.

description.plain:
“Love Me More” is Sam Smith’s first release of 2022 and their come-back to music following their third studio album, Love Goes, in 2020.

Previously Sam posted a preview of the track on their Instagram story. They also sent a snippet of the first verse to some fans on the same day.

The song has a catchy, emphatic beat that stays with the listener.  The lyric deals with the subject of low self-esteem and overcoming self-hatred to achieve a more positive outlook, but does so with a subtle hint of humour and self-mockery.

description.plain:
This, like “Blind Eye”, appeared on the “Thrill Of It All” Target special edition, which was not readily available in most countries.

This song, different in mood and pace to Sam’s other productions, has a hypnotic effect. It tells a different story to the sad love ballads of the first album, that of a young man and a young woman taking responsibility for their respective families.  It also showcases the haunting quality of Sam’s voice.

description.plain:
This, like “Leader of the Pack”, appeared on the “Thrill Of It All” Target special edition, which is not readily available in the US and UK.

This acapella track is different from Sam Smith’s usual style and showcases their voice, with its increasing power as Sam matures. The Gospel backing singers complement Sam; no need for instrumental backing in this short, unexpected song.

The lyric is somewhat obscure, but the sense could be of a relationship between two people who aren’t meant to be together.  Whether forbidden by a homophobic society or racial differences, this is disregarded by the singer — hence the significance of “blind eye”. Other listeners may have different interpretations.

description.plain:
The original of this song, performed with Disclosure was first heard as part of their 2015 album, Caracal, and then issued as lead single. This slower version, available as a download, as a track on the ‘Drowning Shadows’ edition of ‘In the Lonely Hour’ and on YouTube, has Sam Smith singing with spare backing instruments and a completely different mood.

Sam Smith had vocal training since childhood and through his teenage years with jazz singer and songwriter Joanna Eden. Her influence can be seen in Sam’s performance, with his vocal versatility, his ability to explore unusual chord prgressions and improvise variations. The pace is much slower than Disclosure’s, in which Sam sings it as a dance number, but here showcases his wide vocal range and remarkable voice. This is a more specialised version that will appeal to jazz fans.

Detailed annotations of the lyric can be found on the page for the Disclosure version.

description.plain:
This song, composed and recorded by Sam Smith, was released in 2014 in Japan as part of the ‘In The Lonely Hour’ album. The reasons for its exclusion from the version of the album released in all other countries is not known.

The song is characteristic Sam Smith; a compelling, catchy melody and a strong beat. Sam’s voice is as smooth and accomplished as ever. The insistent, thumping drumbeat adds distinctiveness.

The views of fans via Twitter are extremely positive, with many regretting the fact that this is not readily available in the UK and USA, and that it deserves more recognition.

The story it tells is a familiar one, of a deserted lover trying to recover from a failed love affair. There are neat touches in the lyric, such as ‘the cities smoulder’ and the contradiction of ‘the sun is colder’. The reference to ‘a stranger’s shoulder’ is echoed by Sam’s 2019 hit ‘Dancing with a Stranger’.  They may have drawn the later idea from this earlier composition, but this is speculation as they have never commented on this song.

description.plain:
“Laurel Canyon”, along with “Sober” is one of two exclusive tracks from the Target and Japanese editions of Sam Smith’s third album, Love Goes.

This song has a Country and Western flavour that distinguishes it from the rest of the album. Although Sam Smith hasn’t spoken about this track, it would seem to fit with the story of the romantic break-up between Sam and Brandon Flynn in 2018.

body.plain:
“Laurel Canyon”, along with “Sober” is one of two exclusive tracks from the Target and Japanese editions of Sam Smith’s third album, Love Goes.

This song has a Country and Western flavour that distinguishes it from the rest of the album. Although Sam Smith hasn’t spoken about this track, it would seem to fit with the story of the romantic break-up between Sam and Brandon Flynn in 2018.

description.plain:
This is an early song, written and performed live by Sam Smith, but never released. It can, however, be found on Youtube; amateur recordings of live performances in 2013, for example at Hammersmith Apollo Theatre and Mercury Live Lounge. The best recording is of a live performance in May 2013 at St. Pancras Old Church, London. Even this, though, is distorted and the words are difficult to decipher.



The song is fascinating, however. Sam Smith has clearly made huge strides since ‘The Lost Tapes’. The latter are early productions that date back to 2009 when Sam was a teenager, still developing his musical skills.

http://imgur.com/z6k6c0O

In these later performances in 2013 the voice is recognisably Sam’s, with that clear, rich unique timbre. The distinctive falsetto has also definitely arrived. The song is melodic, also unmistakably Sam’s, with the extended range that matches his extraordinary vocal athletics.

The song is clearly loved by listeners, as the comments on social media indicate. One wonders why this was never released, given its popularity.

The weakness—and it’s a small but important criticism—is that Sam’s lyric-writing ability still needs to mature. Some lines work very well, a huge step forward from, for example, the naivety of ‘When it’s alright’. In ‘Skies of Rain’ Sam writes ‘we’re washed up as the driftwood on beaches and you make no amend’—a nice poetic touch. Others lines are a little clumsy, as the analysis explains. But the essential passionate, heart-breaking singer-songwriter Sam Smith has definitely arrived.
